official-title.#text:
To assist in the conservation of rare felids and rare canids by supporting and providing financial
			 resources for the conservation programs of nations within the range of
			 rare felid and rare canid populations and projects of persons with
			 demonstrated expertise in the conservation of rare felid and rare canid
			 populations.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Rare Cats and Canids Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Rare Cats and Canids Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

The purposes of this Act are to provide financial resources and to foster international
			 cooperation—
to restore and perpetuate healthy populations of rare felids and rare canids in the wild; and
to assist in the conservation of rare felid and rare canid populations worldwide.
In this Act:

quote.#tail:
means the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, done at
			 Washington March 3, 1973 (27 UST 1087; TIAS 8249), including its
			 appendices.

text.#text: The term
The term

means the methods and procedures necessary to bring a population, subspecies, species, or taxon of
			 rare felid or rare canid to the point at which there are sufficient
			 populations in the wild to ensure its long-term viability; and

includes all activities associated with protection and management of a population, subspecies,
			 species, or taxon of rare felid or rare canid, including—
maintenance, management, protection, and restoration of rare felid or rare canid habitat;
research and monitoring;
law enforcement;
community outreach and education;
conflict resolution initiatives; and

strengthening the capacity of local communities, governmental agencies, nongovernmental
			 organizations and other institutions to implement conservation programs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Rare Cats and Canids Act of 2014/s:5

quote.#tail: means the Rare Cats and Canids Conservation Fund established by

text.#text: The term

quote.#tail: means the Red List of Threatened Species Maintained by the World Conservation Union.

text.#text: The term

quote.#tail:
means any population, subspecies, species, or taxon in the family Canidae that is listed in the
			 IUCN Red List as near threatened, vulnerable, endangered, or critically
			 endangered.

text.#text: Except as provided in subparagraph (B), the term

quote.#tail:
does not include any subspecies or population that is native to the area comprised of the United
			 States and Canada.

text.#text: The term

quote.#tail:
means any population, subspecies, species, or taxon in the family Felidae that is listed in the
			 IUCN Red List as near threatened, vulnerable, endangered, or critically
			 endangered.

text.#text: Except as provided in subparagraph (B), the term

any subspecies or population that is native to the area comprised of the United States and Canada;
			 and
any tiger (Panthera tigris).
The term
The term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall use amounts in the Fund to provide financial
			 assistance for projects for the conservation of rare felid and rare canids
			 for which project proposals are approved by the

in accordance
			 with this section.

text.#text:
Subject to the availability of funds and in consultation with other appropriate Federal officials,
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: by—

text.#text: A proposal for a project for the conservation of rare felid and canids may be submitted to the

any wildlife management authority of a country that has within its boundaries any part of the range
			 of a rare felid or rare canid, respectively; and

any person or group with the demonstrated expertise required for the conservation in the wild of
			 rare felids or rare canids, respectively.

To be considered for financial assistance for a project under this Act, an applicant shall submit a
			 project proposal that includes—
a concise statement of the purposes of the project;
the name of the individual responsible for conducting the project;
a description of the qualifications of the individuals who will conduct the project;
a concise description of—
methods for project implementation and outcome assessment;
staffing for the project;
the logistics of the project; and
community involvement in the project;
an estimate of funds and time required to complete the project;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines that such
			 support is required for the success of the project;

text.#text:
evidence of support for the project by appropriate governmental entities of the countries in which
			 the project will be conducted, if the
information regarding the source and amount of matching funding available for the project; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
considers to be necessary for evaluating the eligibility
			 of the project for funding under this Act.

text.#text: any other information that the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall—

text.#text: The

not later than 30 days after receiving a project proposal, provide a copy of the proposal to the
			 appropriate Federal officials; and

review each project proposal in a timely manner to determine if the proposal meets the criteria
			 specified in subsection (d).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, after consulting with other appropriate Federal
			 officials, shall—

text.#text:
Not later than 180 days after receiving a project proposal, and subject to the availability of
			 funds, the
approve or disapprove the proposal; and

provide written notification of the approval or disapproval to the person who submitted the
			 proposal, other appropriate Federal officials, and each country within
			 whose borders the project will take place.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may approve a project proposal under this section if the project will contribute to
			 conservation of rare felids or rare canids in the wild by assisting
			 efforts to—

text.#text: The
implement conservation programs;

address the conflicts between humans and rare felids or rare canids, respectively, that arise from
			 competition for the same habitat or resources;
enhance compliance with CITES, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and
			 other applicable laws that prohibit or regulate the taking or trade of
			 rare felids and rare canids or regulate the use and management of rare
			 felid and rare canid habitat;

text.#text: develop sound scientific information on, or methods for monitoring—
the condition and health of rare felid or rare canid habitat;
rare felid or rare canid population numbers and trends; and

the ecological characteristics and requirements of populations of rare felids or rare canids for
			 which there are little or no data;

promote cooperative projects among government entities, affected local communities, nongovernmental
			 organizations, and other persons in the private sector; or

funds will not be appropriated for the purchase or lease of lands to be used as suitable habitat
			 for felids or canids.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall give preference to
			 conservation projects that are designed to ensure effective, long-term
			 conservation of rare felids and rare canids and their habitats.

text.#text: In approving project proposals under this section, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall give
			 preference to projects for which there exists some measure of matching
			 funds.

text.#text: In determining whether to approve project proposals under this section, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: periodic reports (at such intervals as the

considers necessary)
			 that include all information that the

, after consultation with
			 other appropriate government officials, determines is necessary to
			 evaluate the progress and success of the project for the purposes of
			 ensuring positive results, assessing problems, and fostering improvements.

text.#text: Each person that receives assistance under this section for a project shall submit to the

Reports under paragraph (1), and any other documents relating to projects for which financial
			 assistance is provided under this Act, shall be made available to the
			 public.

Amounts provided as a grant under this Act may not be used for captive breeding unless as part of
			 an accredited reintroduction or restoration program.

header.#text: Limitations on Use for Captive Breeding or Display

may convene an advisory group consisting of
			 individuals representing public and private organizations actively
			 involved in the conservation of felids and canids.

text.#text: To assist in carrying out this Act, the
ensure that each meeting of the advisory group is open to the public; and

provide, at each meeting, an opportunity for interested persons to present oral or written
			 statements concerning items on the agenda.
The advisory group shall—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall provide to the public timely notice of each meeting of the advisory group,
			 including the meeting agenda.
